Variables are names (tags, stickers) for Julia objects x = 2 y = x x = 3 x, y ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` (3, 2) ``` ::: ::: ## Data types ### Built-in Data types ::: {#18 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} #Numeric data types for T in (UInt8, UInt16, UInt32, UInt64, Int8, Int16, Int32, Int64, Float16, Float32, Float64, ComplexF16, ComplexF32, ComplexF64) @show T(5) end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` T(5) = 0x05 T(5) = 0x0005 T(5) = 0x00000005 T(5) = 0x0000000000000005 T(5) = 5 T(5) = 5 T(5) = 5 T(5) = 5 T(5) = Float16(5.0) T(5) = 5.0f0 T(5) = 5.0 T(5) = Float16(5.0) + Float16(0.0)im T(5) = 5.0f0 + 0.0f0im T(5) = 5.0 + 0.0im ``` ::: ::: ::: {#20 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} @show typeof([1,2,3]) @show typeof([1.0,2.0,3.0]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` typeof([1, 2, 3]) = Vector{Int64} typeof([1.0, 2.0, 3.0]) = Vector{Float64} ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ::: ### Custom data types `struct`s are basic types composing several fields into a single object. ::: {#22 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} struct PointF x::Float64 y::Float64 end p = PointF(2.0,3.0) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` PointF(2.0, 3.0) ``` ::: ::: The fields of a struct may or may not be typed ::: {#24 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} struct PointUntyped x y end p = PointUntyped(2.f0, 3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` PointUntyped(2.0f0, 3) ``` ::: ::: ::: {#26 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} PointUntyped("Hallo", sin) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` PointUntyped("Hallo", sin) ``` ::: ::: Parametric types can be used to generic specialized code for a variety of field types. ::: {#28 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} struct Point{T<:Number} x::T y::T end p = Point(3.f0,2.f0) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` Point{Float32}(3.0f0, 2.0f0) ``` ::: ::: ## Loops Loops are written using the `for` keyword and process any object implementing the [iteration interface](https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/interfaces/#man-interface-iteration) ::: {#30 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} for i in 1:3 println(i) end for letter in "hello" println(letter) end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1 2 3 h e l l o ``` ::: ::: ## Functions There are 3 ways to define functions in Julia: Long form: ::: {#32 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function f1(x, y) return x+y end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` f1 (generic function with 1 method) ``` ::: ::: Note that the `return` keyword is optional. If it is missing, a function always returns the result of the last statement. Short form: ::: {#34 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} f2(x, y) = x + y ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` f2 (generic function with 1 method) ``` ::: ::: Very useful for writing short one-liners. Anonymous functions (similar to lambdas in python), will be important in the Functional Programming section: ::: {#36 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} f3 = (x,y) -> x + y ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` #1 (generic function with 1 method) ``` ::: ::: They all define the same function: ::: {#38 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} f1(1,2) == f2(1,2) == f3(1,2) == 3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` true ``` ::: ::: ## Multiple Dispatch In object-oriented programming languages methods (behavior) are part of the class namespace itself and can be used to implement generic behavior. ::: {#40 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} using PythonCall ``` ::: ```python class Point(): def __init__(self,x,y): self.x = x self.y = y def abs(self): return self.x*self.x + self.y*self.y p = Point(3,2) p.abs() ``` ::: {#42 .cell execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` Python: 13 ``` ::: ::: In Julia, functions are first-class objects and can have multiple methods for different combinations of argument types. ::: {#44 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} absolute(p::Point) = p.x^2 + p.y^2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` absolute (generic function with 1 method) ``` ::: ::: This defines a new function `absolute` with a single method ::: {#46 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} methods(absolute) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ```{=html} # 1 method for generic function absolute from [36mMain.Notebook[39m:

0.5129811381500429 0.726308818744019 ``` ::: ::: which gets translated to the former expression when lowering the code. ## Differences between broadcast and map For single-argument functions there is no difference between map and broadcast. However, the functions differe in behavior when mutiple arguments are passed: ::: {#70 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} a = [0.1, 0.2, 0.3] b = [1.0 2.0 3.0] @show size(a) @show size(b) @show map(+,a,b) @show broadcast(+,a,b) @show a .+ b nothing ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` size(a) = (3,) size(b) = (1, 3) map(+, a, b) = [1.1, 2.2, 3.3] broadcast(+, a, b) = [1.1 2.1 3.1; 1.2 2.2 3.2; 1.3 2.3 3.3] a .+ b = [1.1 2.1 3.1; 1.2 2.2 3.2; 1.3 2.3 3.3] ``` ::: ::: `map` - iterates over all arguments separately, and passing them one by one to the applied function - agnostic of array shapes `broadcast` - is dimension-aware - matches lengths of arrays along each array dimension - expanding dimensions of length 1 or non-existing dimensions at the end In most cases one uses broadcast because it is easier to type using the dot-notation. ### `reduce` and `foldl` ::: {#72 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} reduce(+,1:10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` 55 ``` ::: ::: What is happening behind the scenes? ::: {#74 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function myplus(x,y) @show x,y return x+y end reduce(myplus,1:10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` (x, y) = (1, 2) (x, y) = (3, 3) (x, y) = (6, 4) (x, y) = (10, 5) (x, y) = (15, 6) (x, y) = (21, 7) (x, y) = (28, 8) (x, y) = (36, 9) (x, y) = (45, 10) ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` 55 ``` ::: ::: `foldl` is very similar to reduce, but with left-associativty guaranteed (all elements of the array will be processed strictly in order), makes parallelization impossible. Example task: find the longest streak of true values in a Bool array. ::: {#76 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function streak(oldstate,newvalue) maxstreak, currentstreak = oldstate if newvalue #We extend the streak by 1 currentstreak += 1 maxstreak = max(currentstreak, maxstreak) else currentstreak = 0 end return (maxstreak,currentstreak) end x = rand(Bool,1000) foldl(streak,x,init=(0,0)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` (8, 0) ``` ::: ::: `mapreduce` and `mapfoldl` combine both `map` and reduce. For example, to compute the sum of squares of a vector one can do: ::: {#78 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} r = rand(1000) mapreduce(x->x*x,+,r) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` 340.7118723795464 ``` ::: ::: To compute the longest streak of random numbers larger than 0.9 we could do: ::: {#80 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} mapfoldl(>(0.1),streak,r,init=(0,0)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ``` (64, 8) ``` ::: ::: # Allocations Last exercise: In a vector of numbers, count how often a consecutive value is larger than its predecessor.
